GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 91.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ANIMAL. A dog, cat, fowl, reptile or other living creature commonly
understood to be an animal.
   AT LARGE. To be off the premises of the owner, not under the control of the
owner or a member of the owner’s immediate family over the age of 12 years,
either by leash or otherwise; but an animal confined within the motor vehicle
of its owner shall be deemed upon the owner’s premises.
   CAT. All domesticated members of the feline species, male or female.
   DOG. All domesticated members of the canine species, male or female.
   FOWL. Chickens, geese, ducks, pigeons, birds or other species commonly
understood to be fowl, but does not include a household pet.
   HOUSEHOLD PET. Any animal harbored or kept exclusively within the residence
of its owner, except for occasional and temporary periods outside the residence
of its owner in connection with the transportation of the animal to and from
the premises of the owner during which time the animal is kept in a cage or
similar enclosure in the immediate custody, control and supervision of its
owner.
   LEASH. A cord, thong or chain by which an animal is directly and effectively
controlled by the person accompanying it.
   OWNER OF AN ANIMAL. Any person owning, harboring or keeping or having the
care or custody of the animal; the occupant of any premises on which the animal
remains or to which it customarily returns daily for a period of ten days is
presumed to be harboring or keeping the animal within the meaning of this
chapter.
   SMALL DOMESTICATED ANIMAL. An animal, other than a dog, cat or fowl, which
is domesticated in its natural state and propagated and kept as a domestic pet
and which, at maturity, will not exceed a weight of 75 pounds and which is not
prohibited by this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.002 ANIMALS AS NUISANCES.
   It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any animal which disturbs
the peace by loud noises or offensive odors at any time in the day or night.
The harboring or keeping of any noisy or offensive smelling animal shall
constitute and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any person creating or
permitting the nuisance to exist, having the right and power to abate the same,
shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.003 HUNTING; CRUELTY.
   No person shall willfully shoot, poison, keep or ill-treat any animal, the
owner of which has complied with the provisions of this chapter. It is unlawful
for any person to hunt or to engage in killing (except as permitted or required
by this chapter), or to inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload, abandon or
cruelly treat any animal within the village.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.004 DISEASED ANIMALS.
   No animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed
to run at large within the village or be exposed in any public place or kept on
any private premises within the village whereby the health of man or beast may
be affected, nor shall the diseased animal be shipped or removed from the
premises of its owner, except in compliance with this chapter and under the
supervision of a licensed veterinarian.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.005 ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES.
   Whenever any nuisance exists under this chapter contrary to the provisions
thereof, in addition to any other remedies provided in this chapter, the
President of the village is hereby authorized in his or her discretion to cause
the same to be summarily abated in a manner as he or she may direct, at the
expense of the party permitting or maintaining the nuisance. Action on the part
of the President shall not affect the right of the village to enforce any other
penalty provided by this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.006 ENFORCEMENT.
   No person shall hinder or molest any officer or person duly authorized
hereunder while engaged in the performance of any duty imposed by the
provisions of this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or
permit any violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§§ 91.007 THROUGH 91.019 RESERVED.
DOGS
§ 91.020 LICENSE TAG REQUIRED; FEE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep a dog within the
village at any time before January 1, 2000 unless the person applies for and
obtains a license on or before July 1 in each year for each dog so harbored or
kept, except for a dog first brought into the village after that day or less
than four months old on that day, in which case a license shall be applied for
and obtained for the dog when it is first brought into the village or attains
that age. It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep a dog within
the village at any time on or after January 1, 2000 unless the person applies
for and obtains a license on or before January 1 in each year for each dog so
harbored or kept, except for a dog first brought into the village after that
day or less than four months old on that day, in which case a license shall be
applied for and obtained for the dog when it is first brought into the village
or attains that age.
   (B)   Application for a license shall be made to the Village Collector, the
application showing the name and address of the owner, the sex, color, breed of
the dog, age and name, the date of the most recent rabies vaccination,
inoculation number and name and address of the licensed veterinarian who
performed the vaccination.
   (C)   Every owner of a dog harbored or kept within the village shall pay an
annual license fee of an amount as established in the annual fee ordinance for
each dog he or she harbors or keeps within the village. Every owner harboring
or keeping a dog born or brought into the village after January 1 in any year
shall pay on or before the date upon which it is brought into the village or
attains the age of four months a license fee for the remaining months of the
year in which the dog is brought into the village or attains that age. Upon the
filing of an application for the license required by this section and providing
proof of a certificate of inoculation as herein required by this section, the
Village Collector shall issue to the owner a license tag conforming to the
requirements of this chapter.
   (D)   Whenever the ownership of a dog shall change, the new owner shall
notify the Village Collector and pay the Village Collector a fee to change the
record of ownership accordingly.
   (E)   If the license tag issued to the owner of a dog is lost or stolen, the
Village Clerk shall issue to the licensee upon application therefor a duplicate
license tag upon payment to the Village Clerk of a fee.
   (F)   Any unlicensed dog harbored or kept within the village in violation of
this section shall be impounded. A dog so impounded may be redeemed as provided
in this chapter upon compliance with this section.
   (G)   All fees required by this section shall be as established in the
annual fee ordinance
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994; Ord. 859, passed 6-14-1999; Ord. 903, passed 4-14-
2003; Ord. 1015, passed 5-11-2009)
§ 91.021 RECORD TO BE KEPT.
   The Village Collector shall keep a complete registry in a book for that
purpose of all licensed dogs, describing same by name, breed, color and sex,
and shall also enter the name and address of the owner or keeper as given and
the number of the license tag issued.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.022 DOG TAGS TO BE ISSUED AND ATTACHED TO COLLAR.
   The Village Collector shall provide each year the number of metal tags as
may be necessary, the shape to be changed each year, having stamped thereon the
year for which the tax is paid, the words “Kenilworth Dog Tax,” and also the
number of the tag, and it shall be the duty of the Village Collector to issue
one of the metal tags to the person having paid the tax upon each dog harbored
or kept by the person, the number of the tag to correspond with the number of
the registry of the dog. Every person harboring or keeping any dog within the
village shall keep the current license tag attached to a collar made of metal,
leather or other substantial material and securely placed and kept about the
neck of the dog.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.023 KEEPING MORE THAN THREE DOGS A NUISANCE.
   No person shall keep or allow to be kept upon the premises occupied or used
by that person within the village, more than three dogs of the age of six
months or over, at any one time, and for any person to keep or use any yard,
pen, place or premises within the village, in or upon which more than three
dogs shall be harbored or kept at any one time, shall constitute and is hereby
declared to be a nuisance. Any person creating or permitting a nuisance to
exist, having the right and power to abate the same, shall be guilty of a
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.024 DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE AND IN PUBLIC PLACES DEEMED A NUISANCE; DAMAGE
TO PROPERTY; FEMALE DOG IN HEAT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dog to cause or permit it to
run at large within the village, and any dog so running at large shall be
deemed a public nuisance and may be impounded. A dog so impounded may be
redeemed as provided in this chapter.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person having a dog in his or her custody
or control to permit the dog to enter upon the private property of another
within the village, without the consent of the owner of the private property,
or to permit any dog in his or her custody or control to deposit any excreta of
its body or to defecate on any private property. A dog so entering upon the
premises of another or depositing any excreta or defecating upon private
property is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be impounded. A dog
so impounded may be redeemed as provided in this chapter.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person having a dog in his or her custody
or control to permit the dog to defecate on any lands or properties owned by
the village or the Kenilworth Park District, including, without limitation, any
street, sidewalk, parkway, park, conveyance or other public place or facility,
unless the excrement is immediately and effectively removed from the property
for proper disposal. A dog so defecating upon any lands or properties owned by
the village or the Kenilworth Park District is hereby declared to be a public
nuisance and may be impounded. A dog so impounded may be redeemed as provided
in this chapter.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any owner or person having control of any dog
to knowingly cause or permit the dog to be on any lands or properties owned by
the village or the Kenilworth Park District including without limitation any
street, sidewalk, parkway, park, conveyance or other public place or facility,
unless the person has in his or her immediate possession a device for the
removal, and a depository for the transportation, of animal excrement from the
property.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person having custody or control of any
dog while causing or permitting the dog to be on any lands or properties owned
by the village or the Kenilworth Park District to knowingly fail to remove from
the property excrement left by the dog.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person having a dog in his or her custody
or control to take or permit the dog, even though on a leash, upon any school,
public playground, public bathing beach or public park premises within the
village, or upon a path or sidewalk extending through or within any premises,
and unlawful for any person to take or permit the dog, even though on a leash,
to enter or be upon any premises where food is sold or offered for sale or
consumed by the public anywhere within the village during the time any premises
are open for use by the public or persons entitled to use the same; provided,
however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs leading
blind persons and dogs on school or Kenilworth Park District property as
authorized in connection with a school or Kenilworth Park District program. A
dog so entering upon the premises, path, sidewalk or place, is hereby declared
to be a nuisance and may be impounded. A dog so impounded may be redeemed as
provided in this chapter.
   (G)   It is unlawful for the owner of any female dog to permit the dog, even
though on a leash, to be upon any street or other public place or on any
private premises without the express consent of the owner or lawful occupant
thereof, while the dog is in heat, and the owner of any dog shall at all times
confine the dog either by a fence or by a leash adequate to restrain it upon
the premises on which it is permitted to be kept. Any dog not so restrained is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be impounded while it is in
heat at the cost of the owner. A dog so impounded may be redeemed as provided
in this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§§ 91.025 THROUGH 91.034 RESERVED.
CATS
§ 91.035 INOCULATIONS.
   The owner of any cat harbored or kept within the village shall cause the cat
to be inoculated for rabies and other diseases as and when required by state
law. Evidence of the required inoculations shall be presented by the owner of
the cat upon request of the Chief of Police or other authorized officer or
agent of the village.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.036 KEEPING MORE THAN FOUR CATS A NUISANCE.
   No person shall harbor or keep or allow to be harbored or kept upon the
premises occupied or used by the person within the village, more than four cats
of the age of six months or over at any one time, and for any person to keep or
use any premises within the village in or upon which more than four cats as
aforesaid shall be harbored or kept at any one time, shall constitute and is
hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any person creating or permitting a nuisance
to exist, having the right and power to abate the same, shall be guilty of a
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§§ 91.037 THROUGH 91.049 RESERVED.
OTHER ANIMALS
§ 91.050 CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep or allow to be
harbored or kept within the village any animal other than dogs, cats and
household pets kept in accordance with this chapter, and one small domesticated
animal kept in accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.051 CONFINEMENT OF SMALL DOMESTICATED ANIMALS.
   A small domesticated animal shall be kept primarily inside the residence of
its owner. When not confined in the residence of its owner, a small
domesticated animal not prohibited by this chapter may be kept on the premises
of its owner outside the residence if kept in a cage or a fenced or enclosed
area or other secure restraint on the premises, the cage or fence to be erected
and maintained in accordance with applicable village building and zoning
ordinances and kept securely latched or fastened so as to prevent the escape of
the animal. Any enclosure or restraint shall confine the animal to the rear
yard of the premises, and the area in which the animal is confined shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free of offensive odors.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.052 INOCULATIONS.
   The owner of any household pet or small domesticated animal harbored or kept
within the village shall cause the animal to be inoculated for rabies and other
diseases as and when required by state law. Evidence of the required
inoculations shall be presented by the owner of the animal upon request of the
Chief of Police or other authorized officer or agent.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.053 RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person to permit any animal of any kind, other than a
cat, to run at large within the village, and any animal running at large within
the village shall be impounded by the Chief of Police or other authorized
officer or agent of the village.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.054 KEEPING MORE THAN ONE SMALL DOMESTICATED ANIMAL A NUISANCE.
   No person shall harbor or keep or allow to be harbored or kept upon the
premises occupied or used by the person within the village, any animal
prohibited by this chapter or more than one small domesticated animal other
than household pets of any age and dogs and cats of the age of six months or
over at any one time, and for any person to keep or use any premises within the
village in or upon which any animal prohibited by this chapter or more than one
small domesticated animal as aforesaid shall be harbored or kept at any one
time, shall constitute and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any person
creating or permitting a nuisance to exist, having the right and power to abate
the same, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.055 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to rabbits harbored
or kept on any premises within the village for noncommercial purposes, provided
that all rabbits not kept as household pets shall be kept in a cage or similar
enclosure as would be required for a small domesticated animal, and further
provided that no more than ten rabbits of the age six months or over at any one
time shall be harbored or kept on any premises within the village.
   (B)   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to animals harbored
or kept within the village on a temporary basis in connection with a circus,
animal exhibition, petting zoo or similar event conducted in accordance with
all other applicable village ordinances.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§§ 91.056 THROUGH 91.059 RESERVED.
DANGEROUS ANIMALS
§ 91.060 FIERCE, VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS ANIMALS.
   No fierce, vicious or dangerous animal shall be harbored or kept within the
village, and any unspayed female dog not confined in a manner as to positively
prevent it from coming in contact with other dogs or with a person not
trespassing upon the person or property of the owner of the animal, and any
animal which shall bite a person or another animal or so injure a person or
animal as to cause an abrasion of the skin, whether or not the injured person
or animal was trespassing upon the person or property of the owner of the
animal, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and may be impounded. An animal is
declared to be fierce, vicious or dangerous within the meaning of this section
when it shows a propensity to attack or bite human beings or animals or which
causes reasonable fear of bodily injury to any person by attacking or
threatening to attack the person.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.061 DUTY OF OWNER OF ANIMAL WHICH HAS BITTEN PERSON OR ANIMAL.
   It is unlawful for the owner of any animal, having knowledge that an animal
has bitten any person or animal, or so injured any person or animal as to cause
an abrasion of the skin, to sell or give away the animal, or to allow the
animal to be taken beyond the limits of the village, except for the purpose
hereinafter provided. It shall be the duty of the owner to place the animal in
a recognised veterinary hospital acceptable to the village, and under the
supervision of a licensed veterinarian for a period of time as the village
deems necessary in order to determine whether it has rabies.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.062 REPORT OF RABIES.
   Every veterinarian or other person discovering any animal suffering from
rabies, shall immediately report that fact to the Chief of Police and shall
give the name, if known, and the place of residence of the owner of the animal,
the place where the animal can be found, and (in the case of a dog) the license
number of the animal, if known. The animal shall be immediately taken up and
placed in a licensed veterinary hospital if not already therein, where it shall
be observed by a licensed veterinarian until the time of its death or recovery.
In the event of its death, suitable pathological examination of the brain shall
be carried out to determine whether or not the animal died of rabies.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.063 ANIMALS BITING OTHER ANIMALS.
   Any animal which has rabies, and any animal bitten by an animal having
rabies, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and the animal may be impounded
and quarantined. It shall be the duty of the person owning or in possession or
custody of the animal to surrender it to any police officer or other authorized
officer or agent of the village upon demand. Any animal which has rabies may be
put to death at the direction of the Chief of Police. In the event any animal
which has been bitten by another is impounded as provided in this section, that
animal may be quarantined for a period of time as the Chief of Police deems
necessary in order to determine whether it has rabies.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.064 AUTHORITY OF OFFICER TO ENTER PREMISES TO SEIZE ANIMALS.
   Any police officer or other authorized officer or agent of the village may
enter upon the premises of an owner of any dangerous, mad, fierce or vicious
animal, or any animal suffering from rabies, or any animal bitten by another
animal afflicted with rabies, for the purpose of seizing it, and if after
request therefor the owner of the animal or an immediate member of the owner’s
family over 16 years of age shall refuse to deliver the animal to the officer
and the officer cannot with reasonable effort catch the animal, he or she may
kill it. Knowledge by the officer of one or more of the facts, the affidavit of
a citizen of the village stating same, or evidence from a licensed veterinarian
that the animal is suffering from rabies, shall authorize the officer to enter
the premises and either impound the animal or kill it if not delivered to the
officer as set forth herein.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.065 PROCEDURE FOR WARRANT.
   Whenever a complaint shall be made under oath and filed with the Chief of
Police setting forth that any animal has disturbed the quiet of any person or
neighborhood, has emitted offensive odors or has bitten any person not
trespassing upon the person or property of the owner of the animal, the Chief
of Police shall issue a warrant against the owner or keeper of the animal and
if upon return of the warrant shall be adjudged guilty of the complaint
charged, the owner of the animal shall be ordered to have it killed or removed
from within the village within 24 hours after the time of receiving a copy of
the order. Any person who within 24 hours after having received a copy of the
order shall refuse or neglect to remove or kill or cause the animal to be
removed from within the village or killed, shall be fined subject to the
general penalty provisions of this code for every 24-hour period thereafter
until the animal is removed or killed; and it shall be the duty of any police
officer to seize the animal for the purpose of its destruction whenever it
shall be found at large within the village after 24 hours after the time a copy
of the order shall have been served upon or received by the owner of the
animal.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.066 DANGEROUS ANIMALS NOT TO RUN AT LARGE.
   No person shall knowingly suffer or permit any dangerous, unruly, fierce or
mischievous animal, being the owner or keeper thereof, to run or be at large,
to the danger, annoyance or damage of any other person.
(1995 Code, § 27-2)
§§ 91.067 THROUGH 91.079 RESERVED.
IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS
§ 91.080 CHIEF OF POLICE EX OFFICIO POUNDMASTER.
   The Chief of Police of the village shall be ex officio poundmaster for the
village and he or she shall appoint deputy poundmasters from among the Police
Department as may be necessary, or the Board of Trustees may appoint a person
as poundmaster or deputy as it deems necessary.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.081 DUTY TO IMPOUND ANIMALS AND GIVE NOTICE.
   It shall be the duty of the poundmaster and his or her deputy and of the
Police Department or other person as may be designated by the Board of Trustees
to take up and impound in the place designated by the Board, any animal found
running at large within the village contrary to the provisions of this
subchapter, and if the animal shall not be redeemed as hereinafter provided
within five days after notice is given as hereinafter provided, it shall be the
duty of the poundmaster or Police Department to cause the animal to be killed
or otherwise disposed of under the direction of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.082 POUNDMASTER; REGISTER AND NOTICE OF OWNERS.
   Immediately upon receiving any animal at the pound, the poundmaster shall
make a registry of the same and enter the breed, color and sex, whether
licensed or not, and the name and address of the owner of the animal if known
or the same can be ascertained; and the poundmaster shall forthwith give notice
to the owner if known or if the owner’s identity can be ascertained, by
registered mail, of the impounding of the animal. If the owner of the animal is
unknown and cannot be ascertained, then the poundmaster shall give notice by
advertising the same in the next ensuing issue of any newspaper in general
circulation in the village or posting public notice thereof at the office of
the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.083 REDEMPTION FROM POUND; IMPOUNDING FEES.
   (A)   The owner or keeper of any animal which is impounded pursuant to this
chapter may redeem the animal unless it is found to be suffering from rabies or
is otherwise required to remain impounded. The poundmaster shall collect from
the owner or keeper of an impounded animal:
      (1)   An amount as established in the annual fee ordinance for the cost
of impounding for the first offense in any period of 12 consecutive calendar
months, an amount as established in the annual fee ordinance for the second
offense in any period of 12 consecutive calendar months, an amount as
established in the annual fee ordinance for the third offense in any period of
12 consecutive calendar months, in an amount as established in the annual fee
ordinance for the fourth offense in any period of 12 consecutive calendar
months and an amount as established in the annual fee ordinance for each and
every additional offense occurring within 12 consecutive calendar months after
a first or previous offense;
      (2)   The amount of the license fee, if any, for the current year, if the
fee has not previously been paid; and
      (3)   The cost of impoundment services and the cost of caring for the
animal during the time it is impounded.
   (B)   The poundmaster shall account for and pay to the Village Collector all
moneys received under this chapter and shall receive no compensation unless
otherwise provided by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.084 DISPOSITION OF UNREDEEMED IMPOUNDED ANIMALS.
   Any animal not redeemed within seven days after the date when it might be
redeemed may thereafter be put to death in a humane manner, or otherwise
disposed of under the direction of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 812, passed 5-9-1994)
§ 91.999 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.
CHAPTER 92: REFUSE AND RECYCLING
Section
   
92.01   Definitions
   
92.02   Duty of owners and the like to keep premises clean; to provide
containers and deposit therein certain refuse materials between collections
   
92.03   Materials, construction, capacity and location of containers
   
92.04   Depositing waste materials in streets and the like
   
92.05   Removal of refuse materials; right to discontinue
   
92.06   License required
   
92.07   Removal fees; schedule
   
92.08   Occupant may elect to remove refuse; notice
   
92.09   Abatement
 
   
92.99   Penalty
§ 92.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AGENCY. The Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County.
   GARBAGE. Any rejected or waste organic matter attending or resulting from
the preparation or use of food, with the paper or other materials necessarily
used for wrapping thereof, and any accumulation of rejected waste, animal,
fruit or vegetable matter which is subject to decay, putrefaction or the
generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors or which, during or after
decay, may serve as a breeding place or feeding material for flies, other
insects or rodents.
   HOUSEHOLD RUBBISH. Includes inorganic incombustible waste such as metal
cans, metalware, bottles, plastic, glass, crockery, stoneware and similar
refuse resulting from the regular operation of a household, not classed as
garbage or miscellaneous rubbish.
   MISCELLANEOUS RUBBISH. Includes incombustible rubbish materials such as
boxes or any waste resulting from the operation of a domestic or business
establishment, such as discarded equipment, but not including large equipment
such as refrigerators, stoves or furniture which cannot be placed in containers
of 40 gallons or less capacity.
   PROJECT USE AGREEMENT. The 1992 Project Use Agreement between the Agency and
the village, as amended from time to time.
   RECYCLABLES. Includes the following if separated from other types of refuse:
      (1)   Newspapers (excluding magazines and other publications not printed
on common newsprint paper);
      (2)   Clear and colored glass bottles, rinsed and with lids removed;
      (3)   Aluminum cans rinsed and flattened;
      (4)   Opaque plastic one-gallon milk and water containers rinsed and with
lids removed; and
      (5)   Other refuse as shall be classified by the village as recyclables
pursuant to rules and regulations in effect from time to time.
   REFUSE. All garbage, household rubbish, miscellaneous rubbish and
recyclables.
   SPECIAL WASTE.
      (1)   All refuse originating from any residential property in quantities
exceeding three 40- gallon containers for one scheduled collection day or
exceeding six 40-gallon containers per week;
      (2)   Refuse materials too large or bulky to be placed in 40-gallon
containers;
      (3)   Construction and similar debris;
      (4)   Rock, stone, gravel or other similar materials;
      (5)   All tree and shrub branches exceeding 36 inches in length or three
and one-half inches in diameter; and
      (6)   Tree and shrub branches bundled as provided in §
92.03(A)(2) exceeding one bundle on each scheduled collection day.
   SYSTEM WASTE. The following types of waste originating from within the
corporate limits of the village and collected by the village contractor or
other licensed person:
      (1)   Garbage, household rubbish and miscellaneous rubbish originating
from residences within the village;
      (2)   Other garbage, household rubbish and miscellaneous rubbish that the
village contractor or other licensed person delivers to the Agency;
      (3)   Recyclables that the village contractor or other licensed person
delivers to the Agency;
      (4)   Yard waste that the village contractor or other licensed person
delivers to the Agency; and
      (5)   Construction and demolition waste that the village contractor or
other licensed person delivers to the Agency.
   VILLAGE WASTE SYSTEM. The waste collection, transportation and disposal
system of the village operated by the village contractor and all other waste
collection, transportation and disposal systems operating within the village
under license from the village pursuant to §
92.07, including all physical assets of the village used for the collection,
transportation and disposal of system waste, all amounts on deposit in the
village waste system fund established pursuant to §
92.06, and all amounts collected on account of rates and charges imposed for
the collection and removal of system waste.
   YARD WASTE. Grass and shrub clippings, weeds, small tree trimmings, twigs,
leaves and general organic yard and garden waste materials, provided that yard
waste shall not include shrub or tree branches exceeding 36 inches in length or
three and one-half inches in diameter or rock, stone, gravel or other similar
materials.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.02 DUTY OF OWNERS AND THE LIKE TO KEEP PREMISES CLEAN; TO PROVIDE
CONTAINERS AND DEPOSIT THEREIN CERTAIN REFUSE MATERIALS BETWEEN COLLECTIONS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, or his or her agent, and of the
occupant or lessee of any house, place of business or premises within the
corporate limits of the village, to keep the premises owned, leased, controlled
or occupied by him or her clear of any accumulation of refuse materials, and to
provide or cause to be provided and maintained clean and in good repair,
containers, as specified in §
92.03, and to deposit and keep deposited therein between collections, all
garbage, household and miscellaneous rubbish.
   (B)   Except as otherwise expressly provided in this section, every owner,
or his or her agent, and every occupant or lessee of any house, place of
business or premises within the corporate limits of the village shall dispose
of system waste through the village waste system. All system waste shall be
collected by or on behalf of the village pursuant to the terms of this chapter
and shall be delivered to a transfer station as directed by the Agency or the
village or as otherwise agreed to by the Agency or the village under the
project use agreement.
   (C)   No owner, or his or her agent or occupant or lessee of any house,
place of business, or premises within the corporate limits of the village,
shall dispose of system waste through the village waste system unless the
system waste complies with all rules and regulations applicable thereto and
established from time to time by the village or the Agency.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.03 MATERIALS, CONSTRUCTION, CAPACITY AND LOCATION OF CONTAINERS.
   (A)   Separate containers, adequate in number and readily accessible outside
of any building upon the premises, shall be provided and maintained on each
occupied premises within the village, and shall be of the following materials,
construction and capacity.
      (1)   Containers for garbage, household rubbish and miscellaneous rubbish
shall be of metal or other durable material, shall have a capacity of not less
than 20 nor more than 40 gallons, and shall be provided with close fitting
covers and with handles for carrying.
      (2)   Except as hereinafter provided, containers for yard waste shall be
disposable, biodegradable, 30-gallon, two-ply, 50 pound super wet strength
paper bags. Branches smaller than 36 inches in length and three and one-half
inches in diameter shall be packaged in bundles measuring no larger than 12
inches in diameter and securely tied with twine or other biodegradable
material.
      (3)   Containers for recyclables shall be as approved by the village from
time to time.
   (B)   An enclosure may be used to hide and protect the containers, provided
it is unlocked and accessible at all times to the person employed or licensed
to remove the contents of the containers, and provided that containers for yard
waste are placed at the appropriate collection point (curbside or alley) at the
time specified in §
92.05(B).
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.04 DEPOSITING WASTE MATERIALS IN STREETS AND THE LIKE.
   Except as otherwise provided in this section or in rules and regulations in
effect from time to time, no garbage, household rubbish, miscellaneous rubbish,
recyclables or yard waste materials of any kind shall be deposited or permitted
to be placed in any street, alley or public way, or in or on any vacant lot,
and all refuse and yard waste materials shall be so placed on the owner’s or
occupant’s premises so that they cannot be blown or scattered about. Yard
waste, placed in containers or bundled as provided in §
92.03(A)(2), may be placed along alleys and the public ways temporarily pending
removal, subject to rules and regulations in effect from time to time.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.05 REMOVAL OF REFUSE MATERIALS; RIGHT TO DISCONTINUE.
   (A)   The village may collect, remove and dispose of all refuse materials
and yard waste, at intervals of time as shall be designated by the village
through contract for the removal thereof, and in accordance with this chapter
and additional rules and regulations as to service, rate of charge and other
matters as may be in effect from time to time. No owner, occupant or lessee of
any premises in the village shall be entitled to service by the village who has
not complied fully with all the provisions of this chapter and with the rules
and regulations in effect from time to time.
   (B)   Subject to rules and regulations in effect from time to time, refuse,
other than yard waste, placed in containers conforming to §
92.03 shall be placed by the owner, occupant or lessee for collection in the
rear or side yard of the premises, except for any premises served by an alley,
in which case refuse placed in containers conforming to §
92.03 shall be placed for collection adjacent to the alley serving the
premises. Subject to rules and regulations in effect from time to time, yard
waste, placed in containers conforming to §
92.03 shall be placed for collection at curbside (no earlier than 6:00 p.m. on
the day preceding the scheduled collection and no later than 7:00 a.m. on the
scheduled collection day), except for any premises served by an alley, in which
case yard waste, placed in containers conforming to §
92.03 shall be placed for collection adjacent to the alley serving the
premises.
   (C)   The village contractor will not collect special waste unless special
arrangements for the collection thereof shall be made with the village
contractor by the owner or occupant of the residence, place of business or
other premises from which the special waste originated.
   (D)   Where, in the judgment of the village, the removal by the village of
refuse materials or yard waste entails the use of an extraordinary amount of
labor or costs, or for any reason cannot be accomplished without disrupting the
orderly operation of the facilities of the village or its contractor for
removing refuse materials or yard waste, the village may decline to remove or
contract for the removal thereof, and the village shall have the right, at its
option, with or without cause, to refuse to continue to collect, remove and
dispose of refuse materials or yard waste at any time it shall elect so to do.
   (E)   If the village elects not to collect, remove and dispose of refuse
materials or yard waste, it shall be the duty of the owner, or his or her
agent, or the occupant of the premises, to cause the materials to be removed at
least once each week and more often if necessary to prevent a nuisance, and
removal shall be accomplished in a manner as not to create a nuisance.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.06 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   (1)   No person, except the village contractor employed for that
purpose, shall engage in the business of removing refuse materials, other than
yard waste and special waste, as defined in this chapter from residences within
the village, without first having obtained a license to do so. The license may
be granted upon application to the village and upon evidence satisfactory to it
that proper equipment is to be provided and will be maintained. Each applicant
for a license to remove refuse materials from within the village may be
required, as a condition to the granting of the license requested, that system
waste be transported to and disposed at a waste disposal site specified by the
village or the Agency.
      (2)   The fee as established in the annual fee ordinance.
   (B)   Any person holding a license to collect, transport or dispose of
system waste shall comply with the following conditions.
      (1)   The licensee shall comply with all the laws ordinances, rules and
regulations pertaining to the collection, transportation and disposal of system
waste as may be enacted from time to time by any lawful authority, including
the state, the Agency and the village.
      (2)   The licensee shall deliver all system waste to the transfer station
designated by the Agency and the village.
      (3)   The licensee shall maintain all equipment used to collect,
transport and dispose of system waste in good repair and working order and
operated efficiently and effectively.
      (4)   The licensee shall collect as agent for and promptly pay to the
village all rates and charges imposed by the village for use of the municipal
waste system.
      (5)   The licensee shall maintain accurate books and records and make
them available to the village upon demand.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.07 REMOVAL FEES; SCHEDULE.
   (A)   Fees shall be charged and collected for the removal of refuse
materials and yard waste by the village, in addition to amounts payable as a
garbage tax which the village is authorized to impose under the statutes of the
state, in amounts as the village shall establish from time to time by
resolution and shall be payable each year at the times the owner or occupant of
the property is required by the village to pay for water service.
   (B)   If the village elects to discontinue collection and removal of refuse
materials and yard waste other than by reason of the failure of an owner or
occupant to comply with this chapter, the portion of the fee which has been
collected and which covers a period for which collection and removal of refuse
materials and yard waste is not rendered, shall be rebated to the person who
paid the fee.
   (C)   The fees shall be adjusted from time to time by the Village Board of
Trustees as necessary to pay the costs of the village for removal,
transportation and disposal of refuse and to make payments of all amounts that
the village may be required to pay under the interim project use agreement
dated as of May 2, 1988 between the village and the Solid Waste Agency of
Northern Cook County, as that agreement may be amended from time to time.
   (D)   The rates and charges imposed for use of the village waste system
shall be sufficient, after taking into account moneys then on hand in the
village waste system fund and the proceeds of taxes levied and to be collected
which have been assigned and pledged to the village waste system fund to:
      (1)   Pay all operation and maintenance expenses of the village waste
system, including all obligations to the Agency under the project use
agreement;
      (2)   Pay as they come due interest on and principal of any revenue bonds
or other obligations payable from revenues of the village waste system;
      (3)   Provide for all unpaid claims; and
      (4)   Provide adequate depreciation and reserve funds for the village
waste system, including reserves for uncollected charges.
   (E)   Any person disposing of system waste through the village waste system
shall pay the rates and charges established by the village pursuant to the
provisions of this section for use of the village waste system. The owners and
occupants of real estate within the village served by the village waste system
shall be jointly and severally liable to pay all rates and charges imposed by
the village pursuant to the provisions of this section. Any person responsible
for the payment of rates and charges imposed by the village pursuant to this
section who shall fail to pay those rates and charges within 30 days after the
rates and charges shall have become due and payable, shall be responsible for
payment of the costs incurred by the village, including the fees and costs of
any attorney and/or collection agency retained by the village for the purpose
of seeking collection of the rates and charges, whether or not suit is
instituted, in addition to all other rates, charges, fines and penalties then
due and payable.
   (F)   There is hereby created and established an enterprise fund of the
village known as the village waste system fund, which shall be separate and
apart from all other funds and accounts of the village as provided below. All
amounts collected from rates and charges imposed under this section shall be
deposited in the village waste system fund, and, together with all other
amounts deposited in the village waste system fund, shall be separate and apart
from all other moneys of the village, except that amounts deposited in the
village waste system fund may be invested together with other funds of the
village.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 649, passed 2-13-1978; Ord. 665, passed 11-13-
1979; Ord. 680, passed 12-14-1981; Ord. 706, passed 2-13-1984; Ord. 734, passed
1-12-1987; Ord. 738, passed 12-14-1987; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763,
passed 6-12-1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992; Ord. 818, passed 6-12-1995; Ord.
860, passed 6-14-1999; Ord. 905, passed 4-14-2003; Ord. 933, passed 4-11-2005;
Ord. 1022, passed 7-13-2009)
§ 92.08 OCCUPANT MAY ELECT TO REMOVE REFUSE; NOTICE.
   (A)   If the occupant or owner, on or before March 1 in any year, shall
elect to remove refuse materials in a manner satisfactory to the village, then
the materials as shall accumulate upon the premises of the occupant or owner
shall not be removed by the village or its contractor and the occupant or owner
shall thereupon be relieved from the obligation for the charges herein
specified other than charges for use of the village waste system, but shall be
obligated to have refuse materials (other than yard waste and special waste)
removed by a person licensed to do so in accordance with §
92.06 and shall be subject to all penalties provided by ordinance for failure
to remove refuse materials. Notice of the election, describing the premises so
occupied or owned and the licensed person who will remove the refuse materials
therefrom, shall be filed with the Village Manager on or before March 1 in
order to relieve the person from the charge for service for the succeeding 12
months.
   (B)   Any occupant or owner who does not, on or before March 1 in any year,
elect to remove all refuse materials from the premises occupied or owned by him
or her, shall be conclusively presumed to have elected that the village shall
remove the same in accordance with this chapter and shall pay the charge
provided herein to the village at the time and in the manner herein specified.
(Ord. 538, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 747, passed 8-8-1988; Ord. 763, passed 6-12-
1990; Ord. 786, passed 3-9-1992)
§ 92.09 ABATEMENT.
   (A)   If any owner, or his or her agent, or any occupant of any premises in
the village shall fail to keep the premises clear of any accumulation of refuse
materials, the Village Manager shall notify, in writing, the owner, or his or
her agent or the occupant of the premises on which the refuse has accumulated.
   (B)   In case any owner, or his or her agent ,or any occupant of the
premises shall fail to dispose of the accumulation of refuse within ten days
after receipt of the notice, the Village Manager or the Village Manager’s
representative is authorized to enter upon the premises and dispose of the
refuse or cause disposal thereof to be made.
   (C)   Any expense incurred by the village shall be paid by the owner of the
premises, and the village shall have a lien against the premises for the
expenses, which lien shall be enforced in the manner provided by law for the
enforcement thereof.
   (D)   Any owner, or his or her agent, or any occupant of any premises upon
which there shall be an accumulation of refuse shall be subject to the
penalties provided for violation of this code.
(Ord. 766, passed 9-10-1990)
§ 92.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.

§ 93.01 BURIALS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION.
   It is unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery, or to bury any dead
person within the village limits, without a permit therefor from the Board.
(1959 Code, § 16-3)

§ 94.01 BARBED WIRE FENCE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain within the village,
any fence constructed in whole or in part of barbed wire.
(1959 Code, § 31-27)
CHAPTER 95: PARKS, BEACHES, WATERS AND PUBLIC PLACES
Section
   
95.01   Hours of use of parks, beaches and waters
   
95.02   Clothing to be worn in parks and on beaches and waters
   
95.03   Conduct in parks and upon beaches, adjoining waters and public premises
   
95.04   Depositing refuse materials prohibited
   
95.05   Fires in parks and on beaches
   
95.06   Animals prohibited in parks, on beaches and waters
   
95.07   Limitation of use of waters adjacent to beaches
   
95.08   Enforcement
 
   
95.99   Penalty
§ 95.01 HOURS OF USE OF PARKS, BEACHES AND WATERS.
   (A)   The park of the village known as Mahoney Park shall be open for use by
the public between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. only from April 1 to
and including October 31 in each year, and between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and
6:00 p.m. only, from November 1 to and including March 31 in each year.
   (B)   No person shall swim or bathe in the waters adjoining Mahoney Park, at
any time.
   (C)   The beach at and adjoining the water works plant of the village,
hereinafter referred to as the Kenilworth Avenue beach, shall be open for
swimming and bathing between the official hour of sunrise and sunset only, or
as hereafter may be otherwise posted at the entry way at the easterly end of
the Kenilworth Avenue entrance thereto, and swimming and bathing at all times
other than between those hours is hereby prohibited. When, in the judgment of
the Chief of Police, the gate attendant or lifeguard while stationed at the
beach, the water is too rough or too cold for swimming or bathing and notice
thereof is given by them, or any or either of them, to any person on the beach
or using the waters adjacent thereto, or notice is posted thereof at the beach
entrance prohibiting swimming or bathing, swimming or bathing is prohibited
while the conditions last. The village assumes no liability for any accident
occurring upon the beach or for any accident or drowning in the adjoining
waters.
   (D)   No person shall swim or bathe in the waters adjoining the Kenilworth
Avenue beach of the village unless the person shall first have paid the charge
which may from time to time be fixed by the Village Board and of which notice
is given by posting at the Kenilworth Avenue entrance to the beach.
   (E)   The Kenilworth Avenue beach of the village, but not the waters
adjacent thereto, shall be open for use by the public between the hours of 7:00
a.m. and 10:00 p.m., only from and including April 1 to and including October
31 in each year, and between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., only from
and including November 1 to and including March 31, in each year.
   (F)   Any person going in or upon Mahoney Park or the beach thereof, or in
or upon the Kenilworth Avenue beach, or into or swimming or bathing in the
water adjacent thereto, during the hours when the park or beach is officially
closed, or who fails to promptly leave the parks, beaches or waters after
notice to so do, shall be deemed a trespasser and be subject to prosecution as
a trespasser.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.02 CLOTHING TO BE WORN IN PARKS AND ON BEACHES AND WATERS.
   No person shall appear in a state of nudity, nor shall any person make any
indecent exposure of his or her person in any park or upon any bathing beach or
in the waters adjacent to any beach.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.03 CONDUCT IN PARKS AND UPON BEACHES, ADJOINING WATERS AND PUBLIC
PREMISES.
   (A)   No person shall use profane, offensive or vulgar language, or conduct
himself or herself in a rough, boisterous or offensive manner, while in any
park, upon any beach or bathhouse in, upon or adjacent to the beach, or while
in or upon the waters adjoining the park or beach or other public premises
within the village.
   (B)   No person shall have in his or her possession or consume any
intoxicating liquors while in any park, beach or other public property within
the village, and the possession or consumption of any intoxicating liquor by
any person while on any public property within the village is hereby declared
to be a public nuisance and any person possessing or consuming any intoxicating
liquor while on any public property within the village shall be deemed guilty
of a violation of this code; provided, that the possession, service or
consumption of intoxicating liquors in any park, beach or other public property
within the village shall not be deemed a public nuisance and shall not be
unlawful if: (1) the possession, service and consumption of intoxicating
liquors is at a particular event held on or within the property known as the
Kenilworth Assembly Hall, located at 410 Kenilworth Avenue, as long as the
property is owned and operated by the Kenilworth Park District and the service
of intoxicating liquors at that particular event is approved in advance by the
Kenilworth Park District Board of Commissioners and is performed by persons or
entities holding a liquor license from the state authorizing such persons or
entities to serve intoxicating liquors; or (2) the possession, service and
consumption of intoxicating liquors in the park, beach or other public property
within the village shall be expressly permitted upon the approval of the Board
of Trustees in the specific case for the particular location and event in
connection with charitable activities or fund raising for charitable or other
similar not-for-profit purposes. Application for the permit shall be filed with
the Village Manager. If and when approved by the Board of Trustees, the permit
shall be issued by the Village Manager or Village Clerk acting at the direction
of the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees may impose conditions and
limitations as the Board of Trustees deems necessary or desirable in connection
with any permit.
   (C)   No person suffering from a fever, cough, inflamed eyes, loathsome,
contagious or infectious disease or skin eruption, shall swim, bathe or go into
the waters adjacent to any park or beach within the village.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965; Ord. 806, passed 10-12-1993; Ord. 1172, passed 7-
18-2016)
§ 95.04 DEPOSITING REFUSE MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall deposit, dump, throw, cast, lay or place any glass, metal,
can, ashes, dust, manure, paper, garbage, rubbish or refuse material or
obstruction of any kind, in or upon any park or beach, or in or upon the waters
adjoining the same, or any public premises within the village; provided,
however, that any materials may be placed in containers which may be provided
for that purpose.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.05 FIRES IN PARKS AND ON BEACHES.
   No person shall light, make or use any fire in or upon any park or beach
unless authorized by permit issued by the Village Manager.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.06 ANIMALS PROHIBITED IN PARKS, ON BEACHES AND WATERS.
   No person, being the owner of or in control of any animal, other than an
authorized service animal, shall bring, drive, lead or permit the animal to go
upon any public premises, park or beach within the village, or in or upon the
waters adjoining the same, and the person shall be deemed guilty of trespass.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.07 LIMITATION OF USE OF WATERS ADJACENT TO BEACHES.
   No person shall bring any motorized boat, float, raft or other watercraft
into or upon the waters of Lake Michigan within 300 feet of any bathing beach
within the village; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall
prevent going into or upon the waters in watercraft for the purpose of saving
human life or property, and provided further, that this prohibition shall not
interfere with navigation upon the waters of Lake Michigan.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.08 ENFORCEMENT.
   The lifeguards, attendants and police officers of the village are empowered
to enforce the provisions of this chapter and to regulate the conduct of
persons using Mahoney Park, the beach and waters adjoining the park, the
Kenilworth Avenue beach and the waters adjoining the beach, and all other
public premises within the village, and persons disobeying the directions and
commands of any lifeguard, attendant or police officer, shall be deemed guilty
of disorderly conduct and subject to prosecution for the conduct.
(Ord. 539, passed 8-2-1965)
§ 95.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.
CHAPTER 96: CIVIL EMERGENCIES
Section
   
96.01   Definitions
   
96.02   Declaration of civil emergency
   
96.03   Orders by the Village President
   
96.04   Notice
   
96.05   Term; extension; termination
 
   
96.99   Penalty
§ 96.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. All words
or phrases not defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, as amended (20 ILCS 3305/1 et
seq.).
   CIVIL EMERGENCY. A “disaster” as defined in the Illinois Emergency
Management Agency Act, as amended. Specifically, and without limitation of the
foregoing, a CIVIL EMERGENCY includes the appearance of a novel or previously
controlled or eradicated infectious agent or biological toxin.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020)
§ 96.02 DECLARATION OF CIVIL EMERGENCY.
   (A)   Pursuant to the authority granted by state law, including, without
limitation, § 11-1-6 of the Illinois Municipal Code, whenever the Village
President determines that a civil emergency exists in
the village, the Village President shall have the extraordinary power and
authority to exercise by executive order all such powers of the corporate
authorities and other officers of the village as may be reasonably necessary or
appropriate to eliminate or minimize the dangers arising from such civil
emergency and for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of
the public; provided, however, that prior to exercising any such extraordinary
power and authority, the Village President shall have executed under oath a
written declaration of civil emergency containing the following:
      (1)   An express declaration that a civil emergency exists; and
      (2)   A statement of facts known to the Village President, either
directly or upon information and belief, which describes the nature of the
civil emergency and substantiates the finding that a civil emergency exists.
   (B)   Unless expressly stated otherwise, a declaration issued pursuant to
this section shall be considered a local disaster declaration made pursuant to
§ 11 of the Emergency Management Agency Act.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020)
§ 96.03 ORDERS BY THE VILLAGE PRESIDENT.
   The Village President may, upon the issuance of a declaration of civil
emergency in accordance with §
96.02 of this code, issue orders to implement any or all of the following:
   (A)   The imposition of a curfew applicable to such geographical areas of
the village or to the village as whole, as deemed advisable by the Village
President, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as deemed
necessary by the Village President in the interest of the public safety and
welfare;
   (B)   The discontinuance of selling, distributing, or giving away of
gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
   (C)   The closure of any business establishment anywhere within the village
for the period of civil emergency, including, without limitation, businesses
selling intoxicating liquors, gasoline, or firearms;
   (D)   The closure of any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking
areas to vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic;
   (E)   The calling upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and
organizations without or within the village to assist in preserving and keeping
the peace within the village;
   (F)   The authorization of the Village President, the Village Manager, or
the ESDA Coordinator to enter into contracts for the procurement of supplies
and services necessary to address the civil emergency that would normally
require the approval of the full Board of Trustees;
   (G)   The incurrence of obligations, the appropriation of funds, and the
provision of emergency assistance reasonably necessary to respond to or
mitigate the civil emergency;
   (H)   The prohibition of increases in the prices of goods and services sold
within the village; and
   (I)   Any other actions reasonably necessary to address the civil emergency
and protect life and property.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.04 NOTICE.
   A declaration of civil emergency shall be: (i) filed with the Village Clerk
as soon as practicable; (ii) promptly disseminated to the news media; and (iii)
promptly posted at the Village Hall, the post office, and on the village’s
social media pages and website.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020)
§ 96.05 TERM; EXTENSION; TERMINATION.
   (A)   Term. A declaration of civil emergency shall expire and automatically
terminate, if not extended pursuant to division (B) below, not later than: (i)
the adjournment of the first regular or special meeting of the Board of
Trustees; or (ii) seven days after the declaration is issued, whichever occurs
first.
   (B)   Extension. The Board of Trustees may by motion extend the initial
duration of a declaration of civil emergency and any orders issued by the
Village President in connection therewith. The extension shall be for the
duration necessary and in the best interest of the village and the public to
address the continuing civil emergency as determined by the Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Termination by the Village President. A declaration of civil emergency
may be otherwise terminated at any time in writing and executed by the Village
President.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter, or of any order issued
pursuant to this chapter, shall be subject to the penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.
(Ord. 1259, passed 4-20-2020)

CHAPTER 110: LICENSES AND PERMITS
Section
   
110.01   Applications
   
110.02   Investigations
   
110.03   Fees and bond
   
110.04   Issuance
   
110.05   Pro-rating fee; rebates
   
110.06   Condition of premises
   
110.07   Validity
   
110.08   Transfer
   
110.09   Change of location
   
110.10   Frontage consents
   
110.11   Record
   
110.12   Inspection of premises and the like; nuisances
   
110.13   Termination and notice
   
110.14   Posting required
   
110.15   Revocation
 
   
110.99   Penalty
§ 110.01 APPLICATIONS.
   Applications for all licenses and permits required by the provisions of this
code or any other ordinance of the village, shall be made in writing to the
Village Manager, unless express provision to the contrary is made, on forms
provided by the village, and shall state the name of the applicant, the permit
or license desired, the location to be used if any, the time covered and the
fee to be paid and any additional information as is required by this chapter or
any other ordinance applicable.
(1959 Code, § 21-1)
§ 110.02 INVESTIGATIONS.
   Where the provisions of this code or any other ordinance of the village
necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of a permit or
license, the person to whom the application is made shall make or cause to be
made by the officer charged with the duty of making the investigation or
inspection, such investigation or inspection, to determine or report whether
the permit or license should be issued. No permit or license shall be issued
until the applicant has furnished all information requested by the Village
Manager or other village official and it is found that all provisions of this
code or other village ordinances with respect thereto have been complied with.
(1959 Code, § 21-2)
§ 110.03 FEES AND BOND.
   All fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the
time of application. Except where expressly provided that but one fee or charge
shall be paid, renewal fees shall be due and payable on the first business day
of the year succeeding the year during which the license or permit is issued.
In case a bond is required for the license or permit, the bond must be a surety
company bond to be approved by the Village Manager and must be filed with the
Manager or other official by whom the permit or license is to be issued.
(1959 Code, § 21-3)
§ 110.04 ISSUANCE.
   In all cases where a license or permit is required by this code or other
ordinance of the village, the license or permit shall be issued by the Village
Manager, except where otherwise required.
(1959 Code, § 21-4)
§ 110.05 PRO-RATING FEE; REBATES.
   In case application for any license or permit is made after the expiration
of six months of the current license year, it shall be issued upon payment of
one-half the annual fee. In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any
license or permit fee or part thereof, by reason of the non-use of the license
or permit, the death or a change of location or occupation of the licensee.
(1959 Code, § 21-5)
§ 110.06 CONDITION OF PREMISES.
   No license for carrying on any business or occupation shall issue when it
appears that the premises or building on or in which the business or occupation
is to be conducted does not comply with the requirements of this code or other
applicable ordinance of the village.
(1959 Code, § 21-6)
§ 110.07 VALIDITY.
   No license or permit, even though issued, shall under any circumstances, be
valid or of any binding force or effect unless issued in strict compliance with
all ordinances in force at the time of issuance; and any license or permit
hereafter issued shall become null and void and of no effect whatsoever if at
any time it contravenes any ordinance passed subsequent to the issuance
thereof.
(1959 Code, § 21-7)
§ 110.08 TRANSFER.
   No license or permit granted or issued may be assigned or transferred,
except as specifically provided, nor shall any license or permit authorize any
other than the person named therein to do business or act thereunder.
(1959 Code, § 21-8)
§ 110.09 CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted
act, may be changed with the approval first had and obtained of the Village
Board in the absence of any provision to the contrary.
(1959 Code, § 21-9)
§ 110.10 FRONTAGE CONSENTS.
   Whenever frontage consents are required for the carrying on of any business
or use of premises, the consents must be obtained in writing and be filed with
the Village Manager at the time application for the license or permit is made.
No renewal of frontage consents shall be necessary for the renewing of any
license or permit. Frontage consents once given may not be withdrawn by any
person who has given his or her consent after issuance of the license or
permit.
(1959 Code, § 21-10)
§ 110.11 RECORD.
   The Village Manager shall cause to be kept a record showing every license
and permit issued, the purpose for which it is issued, the location where the
license or permit privilege is to be exercised, the name of the licensee or
person receiving the permit and the amount of the fee paid. The record shall be
open to public inspection.
(1959 Code, § 21-11)
§ 110.12 INSPECTION OF PREMISES AND THE LIKE; NUISANCES.
   Any duly authorized village official shall have the right and power at any
and all reasonable times to inspect the premises or equipment used for which a
license is required under this code or any other ordinance of the village, for
the purpose of determining whether or not the ordinances regulating the
business, premises or equipment are being complied with. No business, whether
licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a nuisance
in fact.
(1959 Code, § 21-12)
§ 110.13 TERMINATION AND NOTICE.
   (A)   All annual licenses terminate on December 31 of each year unless
issued for a period less than one year or no provision to the contrary is made.
   (B)   The Village Manager shall, not less than ten days prior to the
termination of the license or permit period, except in case of dog and vehicle
licenses and licenses or permits for one month or less, cause a written notice
to be mailed to each licensee and person to whom a permit has issued, of the
time of expiration of the license or permit held. Failure to send out the
notice, or of the licensee or person to whom the permit is issued, to receive
the notice, shall not waive the requirement that a new license or permit be
procured, nor constitute a renewal or waive the requirement for renewal, nor
shall it constitute a defense in an action instituted for operating without a
license.
(1959 Code, § 21-13)
§ 110.14 POSTING REQUIRED.
   It is the duty of every person conducting a licensed business or occupation
in the village to keep the license posted at all times in a conspicuous place
on the premises used for that business or occupation; and it is the duty of
every person to remove the license from the place of posting upon its
expiration.
(1959 Code, § 21-14)
§ 110.15 REVOCATION.
   Any license or permit, excepting permits for building construction, may be
revoked by any officer authorized to issue same for any violation of the terms
and conditions upon which it is issued, or of the provisions of this code or of
any ordinance relating to the license or permit; and it shall be unlawful to
continue to operate any business, trade or occupation, or to continue to
exercise any privilege or authority granted by any license or permit after the
period for which it was issued has expired or after any license or permit has
been revoked.
(1959 Code, § 21-15)
§ 110.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.
