GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 111.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct or operate any amusement in the village which is
open to the public and for admission to which a fee is charged without
obtaining a license therefor; provided, however, that neither this section nor
any other of this subchapter shall apply to exhibitions conducted by religious,
educational, philanthropic or other public or quasi-public organizations where
the exhibition is not given for profit. Unless otherwise provided in a
specified instance, it shall be unlawful for any person to open for business or
conduct or operate on a Sunday any amusement for which a license is required.
(1959 Code, § 4-1)
§ 111.002 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for licenses required shall be made to the Village Clerk and
shall comply with §
110.01 of this code as well as with other requirements specified in any section
of this chapter. No license required by this chapter shall be issued to any
person who is not a person of good moral character or to a corporation or
organization which is not represented in the village by a person of good moral
character.
(1959 Code, § 4-2)
§ 111.003 INDECENT SHOWS; EXHIBITION OF CRIMINALS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit or conduct any
indecent exhibition or amusement of any kind, or to exhibit in any theatrical,
exhibit or other public amusement in the village, a criminal or the body of any
criminal or person who is notorious because of the commission of crime.
(1959 Code, § 4-3)
§ 111.004 RIOTS AND DISTURBANCES.
   It shall be unlawful to present public amusements or shows of any kind which
tend to or are calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance; and it
shall be unlawful for any person to create a disturbance in any audience or to
permit or gather a crowd to witness or participate in any amusement as to
create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks.
(1959 Code, § 4-4)
§ 111.005 EXITS; LIGHTING; OBSTRUCTIONS.
   All stairways and corridors in every building or structure in which
theatricals, shows or amusements are offered, operated, presented or exhibited
for gain, shall be supplied with a supplemental lighting system of electricity,
gas or sperm oil, and the system shall be independent of all other lights in
the building or structure and shall be in operation during the entire period
that the building or structure is open to the public and until the entire
audience has left the building. The word “Exit” shall appear in letters at
least six inches high over the opening of every means of egress from the
building or structure, and a red light shall be kept burning over the sign at
all times at which the building is open to the public. No exit door or gates
shall be locked or fastened in any manner during the entire time that the
building or structure is open to the public. All aisles, passageways, corridors
and exits of the buildings or structures shall be kept free from obstructions
of any kind during any time the building or structure is open to the public.
(1959 Code, § 4-5)
§ 111.006 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and/or Fire Marshal to see that
every exhibition amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is
inspected, periodically if necessary, by a member of the Police and/or Fire
Department, to ensure conformity with fire regulations and all applicable
ordinances and laws.
(1959 Code, § 4-6)
§§ 111.007 THROUGH 111.019 RESERVED.
BILLIARD AND POOL ROOMS
§ 111.020 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate, maintain or conduct within the village a billiard
table, pool table or any similar gaming table open to the public without first
obtaining a license therefor as herein provided.
(1959 Code, § 4-7)
§ 111.021 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for a license required by §
111.020 shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall state the
matters specified in §
110.01 of this code as well as the intended location of the place of business
and the number of tables to be used therein. No license shall be issued to any
person who is not a person of good moral character.
(1959 Code, § 4-8)
§ 111.022 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee for the license required by this subchapter is in an amount
as established in the annual fee ordinance for each billiard, pool or other
table with which the room or place is equipped.
(1959 Code, § 4-9)
§ 111.023 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person shall keep open, operate or use any pool or billiard room at any
time on Sunday, or on any other day between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 9:
00 a.m.
(1959 Code, § 4-10)
§ 111.024 MINORS.
   Minors under the age of 18 years shall not frequent, loiter, go to or remain
in any room or place licensed under this subchapter at any time, unless it be
upon some lawful errand sent by the direction and with the consent and
knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the lawful custody of
the minor; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor or operator of any room
or place so licensed to allow or permit any minor to frequent, loiter or remain
within the room or place in violation of this section.
(1959 Code, § 4-11)
§ 111.025 INSPECTIONS.
   Any officer or employee of the village shall have free access to all parts
of any premises used for a billiard, pool or similar gaming table open to the
public, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of making inspections to see
to the enforcement of the provisions of this subchapter.
(1959 Code, § 4-13)
§§ 111.026 THROUGH 111.059 RESERVED.
CIRCUSES AND CARNIVALS
§ 111.060 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct or operate a circus, carnival or similar amusement
in the village without first obtaining a license therefor as herein provided.
(1959 Code, § 4-21)
§ 111.061 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   The application for the license required by §
111.060 shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall state the matters
specified in §
110.01 of this code and shall specify the place in or on which the amusement is
to be operated.
(1959 Code, § 4-22)
§ 111.062 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for licenses required under this subchapter shall be in an amount as
established in the annual fee ordinance for each day during which the circus,
carnival or similar amusement is conducted or open to the public.
(1959 Code, § 4-23)
§ 111.063 BOND REQUIRED.
   Before any license shall issue, the applicant shall furnish a surety bond to
be approved by the Village Manager, in the penal sum of an amount as
established in the annual fee ordinance, conditioned upon the proper compliance
by the applicant with all ordinances of the village relating to the conduct of
the amusement to be licensed and also conditioned upon the payment of all
damages to person or property occasioned or caused by the amusement or any
equipment or device operated or used in connection therewith, and upon the
payment by the applicant and licensee of all fines and penalties which may be
imposed for the violation of any ordinance of the village concerning the
amusement to be licensed.
(1959 Code, § 4-24)
§ 111.064 HOURS.
   No person shall operate a circus, carnival or similar amusement in the
village at any time on Sunday, or on any other day between the hours of 12:00
midnight and 9:00 a.m.
(1959 Code, § 4-25)
§ 111.065 INSPECTIONS.
   Any officer or employee of the village shall have free access to all parts
of any premises used for amusement, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of
making inspections to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
subchapter and of all applicable ordinances and laws.
(1959 Code, § 4-26)
§§ 111.066 THROUGH 111.079 RESERVED.
USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY
§ 111.080 SUPERVISION.
   All public streets, public ways and other municipal property in the village
shall be under the supervision of the Village Manager, under the direction of
the Village Board. The Village Manager shall supervise all proposed commercial
and non-commercial private activities, events and other uses of such municipal
properties that may disrupt the ordinary and safe public use of such street or
other property. In this capacity, the Village Manager is charged with the
enforcement of all provisions of this code and any other related ordinances
except traffic ordinances.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.081 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person or group of persons shall use any street, public way, public
building, public equipment or personnel, or other municipal property within the
village for any commercial or non-commercial private event or activity that may
disrupt the ordinary and safe public use of such street or other property
without first having obtained a permit from the Village Manager or the Village
Manager’s designee.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.082 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   A person seeking issuance of a permit pursuant to this subchapter shall file
an application with the Village Manager or the Village Manager’s designee, in
the manner prescribed by the Village Manager.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.083 CONTENTS OF PERMIT APPLICATION.
   (A)   The application required by §
111.082 shall be submitted on the form or forms, if any, designated by the
Village Manger and shall include all information and supplemental documentation
required by the Village Manager in accordance with this subchapter. All
applications shall, at a minimum, include:
      (1)   A description of proposed event;
      (2)   The location of the proposed event, including any requested closure
of streets or other public rights-of-way;
      (3)   The date, time and duration of the proposed event;
      (4)   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant and a
secondary contact person.
   (B)   The Village Manager is authorized to require an applicant to provide
additional information that the Village Manager deems appropriate in light of
the size, time, duration, location or nature of the proposed event. Such
information may include, but is not limited to, information relating to the
effect of the event on traffic and neighboring property owners, parking and
shuttle services, security and emergency services, venue and staging
requirements, food and beverage service, use of vehicles or equipment, use of
public buildings or facilities, use of animals, sanitation and waste removal,
and proof of compliance with applicable licensing or certification requirements
for personnel or vendors.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.084 SUBMISSION OF PERMIT APPLICATION.
   (A)   Except as provided in subsection (B) , a completed permit application
must be submitted to the Village Manager or the Village Manager’s designee at
least 30 days prior to the date of the proposed event.
   (B)   An application for a permit to hold a community block party on a
residential street must be submitted to the Village Manager or the Village
Manager’s designee at least 14 days prior to the date of the proposed event.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.085 EFFECT AND DURATION OF PERMIT.
   The authorization granted pursuant to and in accordance with the permit
application shall be limited to the time period therein stated and shall be
subject to any terms and conditions stated in the permit or application
approval. A permittee shall fully comply with all applicable ordinances as if
the same were fully set forth in the permit.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.086 APPLICATION FEES AND COSTS.
   (A)   The applicant must pay a nonrefundable permit fee in an amount to be
established by resolution of the Village Board from time to time. Payments must
be made by check or money order payable to the village.
   (B)   In addition to the nonrefundable permit fee required pursuant to
subsection (A), the applicant shall reimburse the village for all fees, costs
and expenses incurred by the village as a result of the review, issuance and
enforcement of the permit or in connection with the permitted event or
activity, including costs associated with the use of village property,
equipment or personnel as well as engineering and legal fees. Rates for the use
of village personnel, equipment and property may be established by resolution
of the Village Board from time to time, or shall be determined by the Village
Manager based on the actual or estimated costs incurred by the village.
Payments must be made by check or money order payable to the village, or by
electronic funds transfer.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.087 DAMAGE DEPOSIT.
   The village may require the applicant to provide a damage deposit or other
security prior to the commencement of the permitted event or activity, the
amount of which shall be determined by the Village Manager in light of the
nature of the event, activities, persons, property and risks involved.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.088 CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE.
   Upon request of the Village Manager, the applicant shall provide a
certificate of insurance in the amount of $1,000,000, or such greater amount as
the Village Manager deems necessary in light of the nature of the event,
activities, persons, property and risks involved, as evidence of general
liability coverage including bodily injury and property damage, and automobile
liability, if applicable. Such certificate shall name the village and its
corporate authorities, officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees,
attorneys, agents and representatives as additional insureds with respect to
any and all claims which arise out of, or are related to, the applicant’s
activities related to the permit. Upon request of the Village Manager, the
applicant will also provide proof that worker’s compensation and employer's
liability insurance have been provided for any and all employees of the
applicant.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.089 HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT.
   Upon request of the Village Manager, the applicant shall execute an
agreement stating that the applicant holds the village harmless from any and
all claims that may arise from the applicant’s use of the designated public
right-of-way, property, building, or equipment in connection with the permitted
event or activity.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.090 BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION.
   The construction, erection, modification or demolition of any permanent or
temporary structure in relation to a special event or use of public property
for which a permit is issued under this subchapter shall be governed by all
applicable building and construction regulations and permitting requirements.
No permit issued pursuant to this subchapter shall authorize building and
construction activities in lieu of any other required permit, authorization or
approval.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§ 111.091 RIGHTS OF THE VILLAGE.
   As a condition of any permit granted pursuant to this subchapter, the
applicant shall agree that the village may, in its discretion:
   (A)   Exercise control over or otherwise regulate or restrict the use of
public streets, rights-of-way and buildings of the village during the permitted
event or activity;
   (B)   Exercise control over or otherwise regulate or restrict the hours and
general location of the permitted event or activity;
   (C)   Prohibit or order the cessation of any or all permitted activities, or
revoke any permit, if the permitted event or activity is determined to be
hazardous to the public, health, safety or welfare or upon a finding of
violation of any ordinance or any condition or provision of the permit; and
   (D)   Have full and complete access to the permitted event or activity and
permission to inspect all structures, devices, and equipment to be used in
connection with the permitted event or activity.
(Ord. 1056, passed 1-18-2011)
§§ 111.092 THROUGH 111.114 RESERVED.
THEATRICAL AND OTHER PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS
§ 111.115 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to conduct or operate within the village any
theatrical performance, exhibition, carnival, game for hire or other public
amusement, with the exception of motion pictures or other performances
specifically licensed by the provisions of this chapter, or any other ordinance
of the village, to which an admission fee is charged, and which is not
conducted solely under the auspices of a religious, educational, social or
charitable organization, without obtaining a license therefor.
(1959 Code, § 4-41)
§ 111.116 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   The application for the license required by §
111.115 shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall state the matters
specified in §
110.01 of this code as well as the seating capacity of the place of any
intended performance where patrons are commonly seated and whether an annual
license or a license other than annual is desired.
(1959 Code, § 4-42)
§ 111.117 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   Any person securing an annual license for theatricals, exhibitions,
carnivals, games for hire or other public amusements, naming a specific place
or building in which the performances are to be presented, may present therein
any number of performances or theatricals, including motion pictures, during
the year for which the license is secured, without paying an additional fee.
   (B)   The fee for the annual license is in an amount as established in the
annual fee ordinance. The fee for the license other than annual is in an amount
as established in the annual fee ordinance per day.
(1959 Code, § 4-43)
§ 111.118 THEATRICALS IN NON-LICENSED PREMISES.
   No theatrical performance, exhibition, carnival, game for hire or other
public amusement shall be presented on or upon any premises or in any building
which does not fully comply with the requirements of this code or any other
ordinances of the village relating to buildings to be used for theatrical
performances, exhibitions, carnivals, games for hire or other public
amusements.
(1959 Code, § 4-44)
§ 111.119 PROHIBITED THEATRICALS.
   It is unlawful for any person to offer or present any theatrical,
exhibition, carnival, game for hire or other public amusement which has a
tendency to cause a riot or disturbance of the peace; or any immoral, indecent
or blasphemous plays, performances or other theatricals which might suggest or
incite to crime. It is also unlawful for any person to exhibit any posters or
advertisements of any theatrical, performance, exhibition, carnival, game for
hire or other public amusement.
(1959 Code, § 4-45)
§ 111.120 OBSTRUCTING VIEW; OVERCROWDING.
   It is unlawful to permit any person, except ushers or other employees, to
remain standing in a hall or room in which a theatrical performance or other
public amusement for which the patrons are commonly seated is presented, during
the time of the performance, or to permit any person to remain standing therein
at that time. It is also unlawful for any person to admit into any place more
persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements therein.
(1959 Code, § 4-46)
§ 111.121 SCENERY TO BE FIREPROOF.
   It is unlawful for any person to use any scenery in any theater or other
public amusement place other than noninflammable scenery or such as has been
rendered noninflammable by application of a fire- preventative coating.
(1959 Code, § 4-47)
§ 111.122 BUILDING AND VENTILATION REQUIREMENTS.
   It is unlawful for any person to present any public theatrical, exhibition,
carnival, game for hire or other public amusement in any building or structure
which does not contain the number of exits required for buildings or places
intended for those performances or amusements by the provisions of this code or
any other ordinances of the village; or in any premises in which the electrical
wiring does not comply with those provisions or ordinances. All places used for
the exhibition of theatricals or other amusements described in this subchapter
must be kept adequately ventilated during each performance and for so long a
time as the audience remains therein.
(1959 Code, § 4-48)
§ 111.123 AISLES, CORRIDORS AND EXITS NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED.
   It is unlawful for any person to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any
aisles, corridors or exits leading from any enclosure or room in which a
theatrical performance or other amusement named in this subchapter is being
given.
(1959 Code, § 4-49)

CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS
§ 112.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to go in or upon any private residence,
apartment or premises in the village, without first having been invited to do
so by the owner or an occupant thereof, for the purpose of soliciting from the
occupants thereof orders for goods, wares, merchandise or services of any
character or description, or for the purpose of offering to give or furnish or
giving or furnishing any goods, wares, merchandise or services to any
occupants, or to induce, invite, receive or accept orders, or to otherwise
solicit, receive or accept the payment or contribution of money or a pledge of
financial support, without obtaining from the Chief of Police a solicitor’s
permit so to do.
(1959 Code, § 7-1) (Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; CONTENTS.
   (A)   Any person desiring to secure a solicitor’s permit shall apply
therefor in writing over his or her signature to the Chief of Police on forms
provided by the village. The application shall state:
      (1) The name and home address of the applicant;
      (2)   The name and address of the person, company or organization by whom
the applicant is employed or for whom the applicant is acting;
      (3)   The length of service of the applicant with that employer;
      (4)   The place of residence and nature of the employment of the
applicant during the last preceding year;
      (5)   The nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or
services to be offered by the applicant, or his or her employer;
      (6)   The purpose or purposes for which the payment or contribution of
money or the pledge of financial support will be solicited or accepted if other
than in exchange for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise or services;
      (7)   The proposed dates on which the soliciting activity will take place
within the village; and
      (8)   The personal description of the applicant.
   (B)   The application shall be accompanied by credentials and other evidence
of the identity of the applicant and the employer or other organization for
whom the applicant is acting as are reasonably required by the Chief of Police
as necessary to verify the identity of the applicant and reasonably and
accurately describe the nature of the applicant’s activity within the village.
(1959 Code, § 7-2) (Ord. 690, passed 1-10-1983; Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.03 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; EXPIRATION.
   (A)   If the Chief of Police determines after reasonable investigation that
the applicant proposes to engage in a lawful and legitimate commercial or
professional enterprise or fund-raising activity, he or she shall issue the
permit required by §
112.01 of this code. An application for permit may be denied for any one or
more of the following reasons:
      (1)   Failure to provide complete and accurate information in the
application;
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements made by the applicant
in the course of conducting any solicitation activity;
      (3)   Violation of village ordinances or laws of the state in the course
of conducting any solicitation activity; or
      (4)   Conduct of solicitation or other activity in a manner as to
constitute a trespass upon private property within the village.
   (B)   Each permit shall expire on December 31 of the year in which it is
issued.
(1959 Code, § 7-3) (Ord. 690, passed 1-10-1983; Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.04 PERMIT TO BE CARRIED ON PERSON; EXHIBITION.
   The permit required by §
112.01 of this code shall be carried at all times by the applicant, when
soliciting within the village, and shall be exhibited by the applicant whenever
the applicant is requested so to do by any police officer or any person
solicited.
(1959 Code, § 7-4) (Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.05 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The permit issued pursuant to this subchapter may be revoked by the Chief of
Police for violations by the holder thereof of any of the provisions of this
code, ordinances of the village or of any state or federal law, or whenever the
holder of the permit, in the judgment of the Chief of Police, engages in an
activity that would constitute grounds for denial of a permit or otherwise
ceases to possess the qualifications required by this chapter for the issuance
of the permit.
(1959 Code, § 7-5) (Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.06 ACTIONS IN VIOLATION OF POSTED NOTICES.
   It is unlawful for any person to go in or upon, or remain in or upon, any
private residence, apartment or premises in the village, without first having
been invited to do so by the owner or occupant thereof, for the purpose of
soliciting from the occupants thereof or to canvass for orders for goods,
wares, merchandise or services of any character or description, or for the
purpose of offering to give or furnish or giving or furnishing any goods,
wares, merchandise or services to any occupants, or to induce, invite, receive
or accept orders, or to otherwise solicit, receive or accept the payment or
contribution of money or a pledge of financial support, or to distribute any
pamphlet, leaflet, book, brochure or other literature of any commercial,
political, religious or other nature, or to canvass for or otherwise advertise,
advocate or promote any commercial, political, religious or other cause, or to
conduct any survey or poll, if the premises is posted with a “No Trespassing”
or “No Solicitation” or “No Solicitors” or similar notice in a location that is
reasonably visible to persons who enter or intend to enter upon the property.
(Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§ 112.07 RESTRICTIONS ON TIME OF ACTIVITY.
   It is unlawful for any person to go in or upon any private residence,
apartment or premises in the village, without first having been invited to do
so by the owner or occupant thereof, for the purpose of soliciting from the
occupants thereof or to canvass for orders for goods, wares, merchandise or
services of any character or description, or for the purpose of offering to
give or furnish or giving or furnishing any goods, wares, merchandise or
services to any occupants, or to induce, invite, receive or accept orders, or
to otherwise solicit, receive or accept the payment or contribution of money or
a pledge of financial support, or to distribute any pamphlet, leaflet, book,
brochure or other literature of any commercial, political, religious or other
nature, or to canvass for or otherwise advertise, advocate or promote any
commercial, political, religious or other cause, or to conduct any survey or
poll, on any day after the hour of 8:00 p.m. and before the hour of 7:00 a.m.
on the following day.
(Ord. 899, passed 10-21-2002)
§§ 112.08 THROUGH 112.19 RESERVED.
PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS
§ 112.20 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of an itinerant
merchant, peddler or hawker in the village without obtaining a license
therefor.
(1959 Code, § 26-1)
§ 112.21 LICENSE APPLICATION; CONTENTS.
   The application for the license for itinerant merchants, peddlers and
hawkers shall be made to the Village Manager, and shall state the matters
specified in §
110.01 of this code as well as the number of vehicles, if any, intended to be
operated, the kind of article or merchandise to be peddled or sold and the
permanent address of the applicant.
(1959 Code, § 26-2)
§ 112.22 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for an itinerant merchant, peddler or hawker shall be
established in the annual fee ordinance.
(1959 Code, § 26-3)
§ 112.23 LIMITATION ON LICENSEE.
   No licensee under this chapter shall:
   (A)   Cheating or defrauding. Cheat or defraud any person in the village;
   (B)   False representations. Make any false representations to any person in
the village;
   (C)   Bartering, selling goods other than specified in application. Barter,
sell or peddle any goods, wares or merchandise other than those specified in
his or her application for a license;
   (D)   Noise. Make, cause, permit or allow to be made, while upon streets,
sidewalks and public places, any noise of any kind by crying, calling or
shouting or by means of any whistle, rattle, bell, gong, clapper, hammer, drum,
horn or similar device, for the purpose of advertising or of attracting the
attention or inviting the patronage of any person; and
   (E)   Sale of goods upon streets, sidewalks and the like. Except as
hereinafter provided, sell, or offer for sale, any goods, wares or merchandise
in or upon any street, sidewalk or public place within the village.
(1959 Code, § 26-4)
§ 112.24 EXCEPTIONS AS TO PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of the preceding section providing for the sale of goods,
wares or merchandise in or upon any street, sidewalk or public place do not
apply to magazines, books, newspapers, pamphlets or other written or printed
matter which the village cannot, as a matter of law, prohibit the sale of in or
upon those places.
(1959 Code, § 26-5)
§§ 112.25 THROUGH 112.34 RESERVED.
CHARITABLE AND POLITICAL SOLICITATIONS
§ 112.35 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or direct anyone
to solicit on that person’s behalf within the village, by telephone or in
person, for any charitable purpose or charitable organization or for any
political purpose or political organization without having first applied for
and received from the Village Manager a permit for the solicitation.
      (2)   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.
         CHARITABLE PURPOSE or CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION. The same meaning as
those terms are defined in 225 ILCS 460/1.
         COST OF SOLICITATION. The total amount spent on solicitation,
including, without limitation, expenditures for salaries, commissions and
employee benefits for solicitors, the cost of any item distributed to persons
solicited in connection with the solicitation, advertising and promotions costs
and other overhead costs.
          DIRECT CHARGE. The authority to determine the methods that individual
solicitors will use in soliciting and accounting for solicited contributions,
stop a solicitation or revoke an individual solicitor’s authority to solicit
for the applicant
         POLITICAL ORGANIZATION. An organization that expends more than 50% of
its budget for political purposes.
         POLITICAL PURPOSE. Any design to influence the policy, actions or
staffing of any governmental body.
       PROMOTER. Any person who manages, supervises or organizes a campaign of
solicitation.
         SOLICIT or SOLICITATION. Any attempt to obtain a contribution of money
or anything of value by any method, including, without limitation, the sale of
merchandise or services, or requests for gifts, donations, loans, pledges,
advances or promises to pay.
         SOLICITOR. A person who solicits and includes persons who supervise or
direct solicitation.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any applicant for a permit under this section
to knowingly make an untrue statement on the application.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person who solicits for any charitable
purpose or charitable organization or for any political purpose or political
organization to knowingly mislead any person who the solicitor or the holder of
a permit solicits, with respect to:
      (1)   The use of the solicited contribution;
      (2)   The activities and purposes of the organization for which the
contribution is solicited; or
      (3)   The cost of solicitation.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any individual that solicits by authority of
a permit granted pursuant to this section to expend for the individual’s
personal use the contributions solicited, except for contributions received in
the form of salary, commissions or employee benefits which were fixed before
the solicitation began.
   (E)   Subsections(A), (B) and (D) above of this section do not apply to:
      (1)   Solicitation only from people who are on the soliciting
organization’s membership list and had consented to be members of the
organization before the solicitation began; and
      (2)   Solicitation only on the solicitor’s property and not involving
entry onto public streets or sidewalks or other public property or the property
of another and not involving solicitation by telephone.
(Ord. 689, passed 1-10-1983)
§ 112.36 PERMIT APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (A)   An application for a permit to solicit shall be made to the Village
Manager upon forms provided by the village. The application shall be sworn to
and filed with the Village Manager at least 15 days prior to the time the
applicant intends to begin solicitation.
   (B)   The form shall ask the applicant to provide the following information:
      (1)   Names and addresses of persons who will be in direct charge of
conducting the solicitation;
      (2)   Names and addresses of promoters connected with the proposed
solicitation;
      (3)   The purpose or purposes for which the solicited contributions are
to be used;
      (4) The maximum number of solicitors the applicant expects to be active
at one time;
      (5)   The state registration number assigned by the Attorney General
pursuant to 225 ILCS 460/2, if the applicant has a number; and
      (6)   The applicant’s best estimate of the cost of solicitation. The
applicant may pro-rate the salaries, commissions, employees’ benefits or other
remuneration paid to anyone who performs functions in addition to being a
solicitor and provide only the pro-rated portion of that expenditure on the
form provided for in this section.
   (C)   The Village Manager shall have the authority to demand from the
applicant any other information, provided the demanded information is necessary
to determine whether the applicant meets the criteria specified in paragraphs
(B)(1) through (B)(6) above.
   (D)   While an application is pending or during the term of any permit, if
there is any change in the information given in the application, the applicant
shall notify the Village Manager in writing thereof within 24 hours after the
change.
   (E)   The Village Manager shall, within 15 days after the date of the
application, issue a permit unless the Village Manager finds that:
      (1)   Any statement made in the application is untrue;
      (2)   The applicant or any solicitor has, within the last year, engaged
in fraud in connection with a solicitation, or been convicted of crime
involving dishonesty or false statement;
      (3)   The persons soliciting under the direct charge of the applicant or
the applicant will do any of the following:
         (a)   Use a method of solicitation which will violate any other
village ordinance or any federal or state law;
         (b)   Unreasonably impede the passage of pedestrians or vehicles along
public sidewalks or streets or other public property;
         (c)   Intentionally make physical contact with others without their
consent;
         (d)   Solicit at times during which soliciting has been prohibited by
village ordinance; or
         (e)   Solicit without agreeing to clean up or pay the cost of clean-up
of litter in the streets or public places if the litter results from the
solicitation.
      (4)   Within the last 90 days the applicant has had a permit issued to it
under this section revoked.
   (F)   A permit issued under subsection (E) above shall be effective for six
months after the effective date.
   (G)   The Village Manager may grant a permit that limits the number of
solicitors that an organization may use so that there will be no more than ten
solicitors active in the village at one time from all soliciting organizations
combined.
   (H)   The Village Manager shall have the power to prescribe a form of
identification for solicitors. The Village Manager may require solicitors to
carry and produce the identification upon request of the police, any village
official or any person solicited by that solicitor.
(Ord. 689, passed 1-10-1983)
§ 112.37 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   Any permit to solicit issued pursuant to §
112.36 of this code may be revoked by the Village Manager whenever the holder
of the permit shall cease to possess the qualifications or to meet the criteria
provided for in that section as requisite to the issuance of the permit, or
violates any of the provisions of this code or any ordinance of the village or
state law. Revocation of a permit under this section may be in addition to a
fine imposed by violation of any provision of this code or any ordinance of the
village.
(Ord. 689, passed 1-10-1983)
§ 112.38 REVIEW OF DENIAL OR REVOCATION.
   The denial or revocation of a permit to solicit may be appealed to the
Village Board if written notice of the appeal is given within 30 days. The
appeal must be decided by the Village Board within 40 days from the time the
applicant files the notice of appeal.
(Ord. 689, passed 1-10-1983)

(1959 Code, § 6-1)

(1959 Code, § 6-2)
§ 112.52 AUCTIONS IN STREETS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall sell or attempt to sell or cry for sale at public auction
any goods, chattels or personal or real property of any kind upon the streets
or sidewalks or other public places in the village.
(1959 Code, § 6-3)
§ 112.53 EXEMPTIONS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall apply to any public auction or sale made or
conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or process or by
virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed.
(1959 Code, § 6-4)
CHAPTER 113: CIGARETTE, TOBACCO AND SMOKE FREE REGULATIONS

§ 113.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the retail sale of cigarettes
without obtaining a license therefor.
(1959 Code, § 8-1)
§ 113.02 LICENSE APPLICATION; INVESTIGATION.
   The application for the license required by §
113.01 shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall state the matters specified
in §
110.01 of this code. The Village Clerk shall refer the application to the Chief
of Police. The Chief of Police or a member of the Police Department designated
by him or her shall investigate the character of the applicant. The Chief of
Police shall make a recommendation as to whether the license shall issue, and
no license shall issue unless he or she recommends it. No license shall be
issued to any person who is not a person of good character.
(1959 Code, § 8-2)
§ 113.03 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee shall be an amount established in the annual fee ordinance.
(1959 Code, § 8-3)
§ 113.04 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   The premises or building used for the purpose of the sale of cigarettes must
be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It is the duty of the Chief of
Police to make, or cause to be made, inspections as are necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(1959 Code, § 8-4)
§ 113.05 SALE, POSSESSION AND USE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning. All terms, phrases, and words used in this chapter but not
defined in this section shall have meaning given to them elsewhere in the
village code.
      MINOR. A person under the age of 18 years.
      TOBACCO PRODUCT. Any item, project or substance containing or made from
tobacco leaf, including specifically, but without limitation cigarettes,
cigars, snuff and pipe, chewing or dipping tobacco.
   (B)   Sale by minors. It shall be unlawful for any minor to sell, dispense,
furnish or otherwise distribute any tobacco product to any person or business
within the corporate limits of the village.
   (C)   Sale to minors. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give,
dispense, furnish or otherwise distribute tobacco product to any minor within
the corporate limits of the village.
   (D)   Purchase by minors. It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase or
otherwise acquire any tobacco product within the corporate limits of the
village.
   (E)   Possession and use by minors. It shall be unlawful for any minor to
possess or use a tobacco product within the corporate limits of the village;
provided, however, that the possession or use of any tobacco product by any
minor under the direct supervision and control of the parent or guardian of any
minor in the privacy of the parent’s or guardian’s home shall not be unlawful.
   (F)   Sale of cigarettes containing harmful drugs prohibited. It is unlawful
for any person to sell or offer for sale any cigarette containing any harmful
drugs other than tobacco.
(1959 Code, §§ 8-5 and 8-6) (Ord. 1003, passed 9-8-2008)
§ 113.06 SMOKE FREE REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Background. Smoking creates the hazard of injury to the personal
health of those in the environment of smoke as well as the potential damage to
property which may result from the combustible nature of the substance. It has
been determined that breathing ambient smoke is a health hazard to both smokers
and nonsmokers. Cigarette smoking also produces several substances that are
considered hazardous to health including carbon monoxide, hydrogen cyanide,
nitrous oxide and formaldehyde. Secondhand smoke (68% of the smoke produced by
a cigarette) affects the health of a bystander, interfering with respiratory
tract defenses, often causing nonsmokers to have allergic or irritative
reactions, and is a known cause of lung cancer. Because the hazards of smoking
have a potentially harmful effect, material and direct, on the public health,
safety, welfare, comfort and property of residents of the village, it is,
therefore, necessary and desirable to establish regulations that prohibit
smoking in enclosed public places and places of employment.
   (B)   Purpose. This section may be cited as the “Kenilworth Smoke Free
Ordinance,” the purpose of which is to protect the public health, comfort and
environment by prohibiting smoking in enclosed public places and places of
employment, in order to ensure that nonsmokers may breathe air free from the
hazardous effects of secondhand smoke.
   (C)   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning. If a word or phrase is not specifically defined in this
section it shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the Smoke Free Illinois
Act.
      ENTRANCE.
         (a)   The doorway or other entrance to a public place that is open to,
and intended for the use by, the general public for ingress and egress to the
public place; and
         (b)   The doorway or other entrance to a place of employment that is
open to, and intended for use by, the general public or business invitees for
ingress and egress to a place of employment, or where employees are required or
permitted to enter or exit.
      PUBLIC PLACE. The portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to
the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or
in part by private persons or entities, or any public entity and regardless of
whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance, as set
forth in the Smoke Free Illinois Act, of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows
that open and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited. A PUBLIC PLACE does not include a private residence unless the
private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care or
similar social service care on the premises.
      SMOKE FREE ILLINOIS ACT. The Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et
seq., as it may be amended from time to time.
   (D)   Acknowledgment of applicability of the Smoke Free Illinois Act.
      (1)   Applicability of the Smoke Free Illinois Act. The village hereby
acknowledges that the Smoke Free Illinois Act is applicable, and is in full
force and effect, within the village. No person shall smoke in any place in the
village where smoking is prohibited pursuant to the Smoke Free Illinois Act.
      (2)   Most restrictive provision controls. In the event of a conflict
between the Smoke Free Illinois Act and the provisions of this section, the
most restrictive provision shall control.
   (E)   Prohibitions; smoking in public places, places of employment and
governmental vehicles prohibited. No person shall smoke in a public place or in
any place of employment or within 15 feet of any entrance to a public place or
place of employment. No person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased or
operated by the state or a political subdivision of the state. Smoking is
prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted
by the Smoke Free Illinois Act.
   (F)   Signs and ashtrays. Each owner, operator, manager or other person in
control of any place within which smoking is prohibited pursuant to this
section shall:
      (1)   Conspicuously post signs indicating that smoking is prohibited in
the same manner as is provided in §§ 20(a) and 20(b) of the Smoke Free Illinois
Act, 410 ILCS 82/20(a) and 20(b); provided, however, that in the event that
there is no clearly defined entrance to a place within which smoking is
prohibited pursuant to this section, the signs shall be posted on or adjacent
to an existing identification sign located on the property; and
      (2)    Remove all ashtrays from the place within which smoking is
prohibited, in the same manner as provided in § 20(c) of the Smoke Free
Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/20(c).
   (G)   Owner and occupant responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any person
who is the owner, occupant or lessee of any place where smoking is prohibited
pursuant to this section to permit smoking in that place.
(Ord. 1003, passed 9-8-2008)
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 114.01 DEFINITION OF FOOD.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FOOD. Includes any edible or beverage used or intended for human
consumption.
(1959 Code, § 13-1)
§ 114.02 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Each application for a license to conduct a business connected with the
storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human
consumption shall be in writing and shall be referred to the Health Officer,
who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises to be used,
and report his or her findings thereon, recommending or advising against the
issuance of the license.
(1959 Code, § 13-2)
§ 114.03 DOUBLE LICENSING.
   Any person licensed to sell any of the foods or beverages for the sale of
which a license is required by the provisions of this chapter, or licensed to
conduct any business licensed by the terms of this chapter, may conduct on the
same premises and in connection with the licensed business any other business
mentioned in this chapter without paying any additional fee therefor; provided,
that the fee is paid for the other business so conducted. This section does not
relieve any applicant from the regulatory requirements applicable to either
business.
(1959 Code, § 13-3)
§ 114.04 REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   Any food dealer’s license may be revoked by the Health Officer for
violations of the provisions of this chapter, or for any violations of any
other ordinances of the village or provisions of this code relating to the
conduct of the business, the condition of the premises or the licensee.
(1959 Code, § 13-4) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.05 UNWHOLESOME FOOD.
   (A)   No person shall sell, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of
selling or offering for sale any food of any kind intended for human
consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for human
consumption for any reason.
   (B)   All tainted or unwholesome food intended for human consumption may be
condemned by the Health Officer and shall thereupon be seized and destroyed by
him, her or any police officer.
(1959 Code, § 13-5)
§ 114.06 ADULTERATION.
   It is unlawful to sell, offer for sale or keep for any purpose, any food or
drink intended for human consumption, which has been adulterated by any
material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the state federal,
or local statutes, regulations, or laws governing the same.
(1959 Code, § 13-6) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.07 SANITARY REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Premises. The premises, building and vending machines used for the
sale of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition. It is unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse or
waste of any kind, any decaying animal or plant matter, to remain thereon or
therein.
   (B)   Unwrapped food. No unwrapped food shall be displayed or stored in any
food dealer’s establishment unless the same is effectually screened, protected
against insects and rodents and otherwise protected from outside contamination.
   (C)   Display outside building. No foods shall be displayed outside the
doors of any building unless they be enclosed in a glass case or container
impervious to insect bites, animals or other outside contamination.
   (D)   Keeping in open shelves and the like. No foods shall be kept in open
shelves or display cases nor exposed less than 18 inches above the floor.
   (E)   Sleeping in room used to store or keep. No person shall be allowed to
sleep in any room used to store or keep food intended for sale for human
consumption.
   (F)   Expectorating. It is unlawful for any person to expectorate on the
floor, walls, furniture, equipment or appliances of any food establishment.
(1959 Code, § 13-7)
§ 114.08 FLIES, RODENTS AND VERMIN.
   Premises used for the storage of food intended for human consumption shall
be kept free from flies, rodents and vermin of all kinds.
(1959 Code, § 13-8)
§ 114.09 EMPLOYEES AND THE LIKE TO KEEP CLEAN AND FREE FROM DISEASE;
EXAMINATION.
   (A)   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food
intended for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person
and clothing, and shall not have any contagious or infectious diseases while
preparing or serving food that could be passed to those who consume or handle
the food.
   (B)   The Health Officer may require any person engaged in handling or
coming in contact with foods to submit to an examination or produce a
certificate from a reputable physician showing that the provisions of this
section are being complied with.
(1959 Code, § 13-9) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.10 INSPECTIONS.
   The Health Officer or the Health Officer's designee shall make inspections
and recommendations as are necessary to carry out the regulations of this
chapter.
(1959 Code, § 13-10) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.11 ADOPTION OF THE ILLINOIS FOOD CODE.
   The "Food Service Sanitation Code", 77 Ill. Admin. Code 750, as may be
amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference as though fully set
forth herein, except where it is in direct conflict with other sections of this
code, and any further amendments to said rules and regulations shall be
automatically adopted, and such regulations shall apply to all establishments
in the village that engage in storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or
drink intended for human consumption.
(Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§§ 114.12 THROUGH 114.19 RESERVED
RESTAURANTS
§ 114.20 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   RESTAURANT. A place, house or room where meals, short-order lunches,
sandwiches or prepared foods are sold for public consumption, on or off the
premises.
(1959 Code, § 13-46)
§ 114.21 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant in the village without
obtaining a license therefor.
(1959 Code, § 13-47)
§ 114.22 RESERVED.
§ 114.23 ISSUANCE AND INVESTIGATION PREREQUISITE.
   (A)   The Health Officer shall from time to time issue licenses authorizing
the operating of restaurants within the village, in the following manner and
not otherwise.
   (B)   Any person desiring a license to operate a restaurant shall make a
written application for that purpose to the Health Officer. The application
shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant, if an individual, all the
members of a firm, if a co-partnership, and the persons in charge of the
business, if a corporation, is or are persons of good character and reputation,
and also that the premises where the restaurant is proposed to be operated are
proper and suitable for that purpose from a hygienic and sanitary standpoint.
   (C)   If the Health Officer is satisfied that an applicant is of good
character and reputation, and suitable to be authorized to operate a
restaurant, and that the premises where it is proposed to operate the
restaurant are proper and suitable for the purpose from a hygienic and sanitary
standpoint, the Health Officer shall issue or cause to be issued a license in
accordance with the application
(1959 Code, § 13-49) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.24 FEE.
   The annual license fee for licenses issued under this subchapter is in an
amount as established in the annual fee ordinance.
(1959 Code, § 13-50)
§ 114.25 POSTING.
   Every person licensed to operate a restaurant shall immediately post the
license required by this subchapter or cause it to be posted in a conspicuous
place within the premises where the restaurant is authorized to be operated.
Any person who violates the provisions of this section, or who, not being
properly licensed, shall cause or permit any paper or document purporting to be
a license to be or remain posted shall, on conviction, be punished as provided
in §
114.99 of this code.
(1959 Code, § 13-51)
§ 114.26 REVOCATION.
   Any license issued under this subchapter may be revoked by the Board of
Trustees by notice in writing, whenever it shall appear to its satisfaction
that the person so licensed has violated the provisions of any law of the
state, this code or any ordinance of the village relative to the keeping of
restaurants.
(1959 Code, § 13-52) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.27 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   It is the duty of every keeper of a restaurant to at all times keep
the premises wherein the restaurant is located clean and in a proper hygienic
and sanitary condition. All utensils, appliances, vessels, receptacles,
refrigerators, pantries, rooms and any other place or thing whatsoever, which
is used for the purpose of storage, preparation, cooking or serving of foods,
must at all times be kept in a clean, wholesome and sanitary condition. No
decayed, decaying, unwholesome or impure food of any kind whatsoever shall be
kept, sold, offered for sale or served in any restaurant. No person shall
reside in any room in which food is prepared or served, nor in any room
connecting directly by a door with a room in which food is prepared or served.
   (B)   Every person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall,
upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in §
114.99 of this code.
(1959 Code, § 13-53)
§ 114.28 INSPECTIONS.
   It is the duty of the Health Officer or the Health Officer's designee, and
he or she is authorized and empowered, from time to time, to inspect and
examine all premises wherein restaurants are conducted, for the purpose of
ascertaining whether this subchapter and all ordinances of the village and the
laws of the state relative to the keeping of restaurants are being complied
with at the place; and it is his or her duty to cause all ordinances and laws
to be strictly enforced. It is the duty of every keeper of a restaurant to
permit the inspections to be made, and when required, to furnish samples of any
foods kept, sold, offered for sale or served in a restaurant, which samples
shall be examined or analyzed by or under the direction of the Health Officer;
and a record of each examination or analysis shall be made and kept on file in
his or her office.
(1959 Code, § 13-54) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.29 ADOPTION OF THE ILLINOIS FOOD CODE.
   The "Food Service Sanitation Code", 77 Ill. Admin. Code 750, as may be
amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference as though fully set
forth herein, except where it is in direct conflict with other sections of this
code, and any future amendments to said rules and regulations shall be
automatically adopted, and such regulations shall apply to all restaurants in
the village.
(Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.30 GRADES OF RESTAURANTS; FAILURE TO QUALIFY.
   No restaurants shall be operated within the village except grade A, grade B
or approved itinerant restaurants; provided, that when any restaurant fails to
qualify for any of these grades the Health Officer is authorized to suspend the
license, or in lieu thereof, to degrade the restaurant and permit its operation
during a temporary period not exceeding 30 days.
(1959 Code, § 13-56) (Ord. 1293, passed 11-15-2021)
§ 114.31 ENFORCEMENT OF §§ 114.29 AND 114.30 OF THIS CODE BY HEALTH OFFICER.
   Section 114.29 of this code and the unabridged form of ordinance adopted
thereby and §
114.30 of this code shall be enforced by the Health Officer of the village, or
his or her authorized representative, in accordance with the interpretations
thereof contained in the 1943 Edition of the U.S. Public Health Service Code
Regulating Eating and Drinking Establishments, three copies of which have been
on file in the office of the Village Clerk more than 15 days prior to the
adoption of the sections.
(1959 Code, § 13-57)
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty provisions of §
10.99 of this code, except where another specific penalty is provided.
CHAPTER 115: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
Section
   
115.01   License required
   
115.02   License fee
   
115.03   Records and reports; when moneys to be paid into treasury
   
115.04   Collection of moneys due by suit
   
115.05   Brokers not to deal with corporations failing to comply with chapter
   
115.06   Establishment of Foreign Fire Insurance Fund
Statutory reference:
   Foreign fire insurance company fee, see 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq.
§ 115.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any corporation, company or association, not incorporated
under the laws of the state, to engage in the village in effecting fire
insurance, or to transact any business of fire insurance in the village, while
in default by not fully complying with any of the requirements of this chapter,
and until these requirements shall have been fully complied with; but this
provision does not relieve any company, corporation or association from payment
of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this chapter.
(1959 Code, § 14-1)
§ 115.02 LICENSE FEE.
   Any corporation, company or association referred to in §
115.01, which is engaged in the village in effecting fire insurance, shall pay
to the Village Treasurer a sum of money equal in amount to 2% per annum of the
gross receipts received for premiums by all agents of that corporation, company
or association, during the year ending July 1, for any insurance, effected or
agreed to be effected, in the village, by or with the corporation, company or
association during that year.
(1959 Code, § 14-2)
§ 115.03 RECORDS AND REPORTS; WHEN MONEYS TO BE PAID INTO TREASURY.
   Every person acting as agent in the village for or on behalf of any
corporation, company or association covered by this chapter shall, on or before
July 15 of every year, render to the Village Treasurer a full, true and just
account verified by his or her oath, of all premiums which during the year
ending July 1 preceding the report, have been received by him, her or some
other person for him or her, in the behalf of any corporation, company or
association. That agent shall also, at the time of rendering the report, pay to
the Village Treasurer the sum of money for which the company, corporation or
association, represented by him or her is chargeable, by virtue of the
provisions of this chapter.
(1959 Code, § 14-3)
§ 115.04 COLLECTION OF MONEYS DUE BY SUIT.
   (A)   The sum of money for which any company, corporation or association is
so chargeable under the provisions of this chapter may be recovered of it, or
its agent, by action in the name of and for the use of the village as for money
had and received.
   (B)   Nothing in this section exempts any person, corporation, company or
association from indictment and conviction under the provisions of any act of
the state.
(1959 Code, § 14-4)
§ 115.05 BROKERS NOT TO DEAL WITH CORPORATIONS FAILING TO COMPLY WITH CHAPTER.
   No insurance broker in the village shall have any insurance business or
dealings with any company, association or corporation not incorporated under
the laws of this state which shall be in default for not reporting or making
payment as provided in this chapter, until it shall have complied with all of
the requirements of this chapter.
(1959 Code, § 14-5)
§ 115.06 ESTABLISHMENT OF FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE FUND.
   There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance Fund to be managed and
administered by the Foreign Fire Insurance Board in accordance with §
33.092 of this code. The Foreign Fire Insurance Fund shall be operated on a
fiscal year from January 1 to December 31. Each year, the Village Treasurer
shall transfer any Foreign Fire Insurance license fees collected by the village
into the Foreign Fire Insurance Fund. As part of the annual village audit, the
funds in the Foreign Fire Insurance Fund shall be audited to verify that the
funds have been expended by that Foreign Fire Insurance Board only for the
maintenance, use, and benefit of the Fire Department.
